results.title: A Trail of destruction
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Jeremy Somerville and ACMI
results.brief_description:
The whole thing probably lasted about twenty seconds, but for Jeremy Somerville, his family and community, it is an event they will never forget.
On the 3rd of June 2010, the residents of Lennox Head, on the North Coast of New South Wales, were preparing for the day ahead when their town was struck by a tornado.

results.title: A Track winding back (A)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
This documentary is based on a true story written by school teacher Carolyn Landon about bushman, Daryl Tonkin and his life and memories of Jackson’s Track in West Gippsland, Victoria. It is a story of love and tragedy, of an Aboriginal community living and working harmoniously with white people in the timber industry in the forest area of Jackson’s Track established by Daryl and his brother Harry during the 1930s. It tells of Daryl’s feud with his family when he decided to live with an Aboriginal woman, the dramatic kidnapping of this woman by his brother, Daryl’s life with the Aboriginal community and the eventual bull-dozing of the camp in the 1960s to appease local Christian groups resulting in the break-up and dispersal of the almost 100 people living at the camp. Daryl talks of himself as being at one with the Aboriginal way of life, a true bushman, who saw his life neither primitive nor of poverty and hardship, but as being his preferred way of life. Includes interviews with two of his nine children, re-enactments, stills and archival footage, and excerpts from the film “Rose against the odds”. Contains some b&w images.

Daryl talks of himself as being at one with the Aboriginal way of life, a true bushman, who saw his life neither primitive nor of poverty and hardship, but as being his preferred way of life. Includes interviews with two of his nine children, re-enactments, stills and archival footage, and excerpts from the film “Rose against the odds”. Contains some b&w images.
description_for_label:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
This documentary is based on a true story written by school teacher Carolyn Landon about bushman, Daryl Tonkin and his life and memories of Jackson’s Track in West Gippsland, Victoria. It is a story of love and tragedy, of an Aboriginal community living and working harmoniously with white people in the timber industry in the forest area of Jackson’s Track established by Daryl and his brother Harry during the 1930s. It tells of Daryl’s feud with his family when he decided to live with an Aboriginal woman, the dramatic kidnapping of this woman by his brother, Daryl’s life with the Aboriginal community and the eventual bull-dozing of the camp in the 1960s to appease local Christian groups resulting in the break-up and dispersal of the almost 100 people living at the camp. Daryl talks of himself as being at one with the Aboriginal way of life, a true bushman, who saw his life neither primitive nor of poverty and hardship, but as being his preferred way of life. Includes interviews with two of his nine children, re-enactments, stills and archival footage, and excerpts from the film “Rose against the odds”. Contains some b&w images.

results.title: A Track winding back
results.brief_description: Presents a sketch of life in Gundagai, NSW around the turn of the century utilising contemporary photographs and written records. Covers architecture, fashion, medicine, politics, problems of workers, the departure of troops for the Boer War and the celebration of Commonwealth Day.

results.title: A Town that died: Walhalla
results.creator_credit: Clifford Pleak and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: Retraces the founding of the town of Walhalla after the discovery of gold. Illustrates the gold boom era, growth of the town and its eventual decline as the gold supply dimished.

results.title: A Town like Alice
results.creator_credit: Henry Crawford, Crawford Productions and David Stevens
results.brief_description: Based on Nevil Shute’s best selling novel, “A Town Like Alice” is set against the brutal chaos of World War 11 and centres on two prisoners of war an Englishwoman, Jean Paget and an Australian soldier Joe Harmon, whose romance begins during the takeover of Malaya in World War 11 and takes them to the vast Australian outback.

results.title: A Town like Alice
results.creator_credit: Joseph Janni, Rank Organisation Film Productions and Jack Lee
results.brief_description: Virginia McKenna and Peter Finch give towering performances in this moving story about a party of women compelled to trek through the Malayan jungle during World War II, because no Japanese officer will take responsibility for their care and feeding. Based on Nevil Shute’s best-selling novel, the film tells how the women come to terms with their hardships, and how they are befriended by a tough Australian prisoner of war who dreams of returning to his home town of Alice Springs.

results.title: A Touch of zen
results.creator_credit: Hsia Liang-fang, Optimum Releasing and King Hu
results.brief_description: Made long before “Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon” this wonderful martial arts epic will linger with you both for its atmospheric and mystical images and its lyrical and mysterious storyline. Set during the time of the Ming Dynasty in a rural village outside Peking, the story begins with the artist Ku Shen-chai who lives with his mother in a supposedly haunted, run-down fort. The arrival of a stranger, Ou-Yang Yin, to the village stirs the curiosity within Ku only to be further flamed by the sudden appearance of a beautiful woman named Yang Hui-Ching. Plot and sub-plot are interwoven to form an intricate tale binding the three protagonists in a web of intrigue and mystery. This is not a full-on action-packed martial arts film but the scenes of combat are impressively creative and beautifully performed. Cast includes Hsu Feng, Tien Peng, Hsueh Han, Shih Chun, Pai Ying. Photography by Hua Hui-ying.

results.title: A Touch of the terminals
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission. Creative Development Branch and Philip Bull
results.brief_description: Its the machine age, computers are taking over - reducing the workforce and increasing productivity. The unemployed can’t afford to buy the products produced and therefore the company can’t sell its products and is losing money. To make money they cull more workers, bring in more machines and again more unemployed who can’t afford to buy. A satirical look at the effects of computers. Cast includes Martin Vaughan, Michael Ross, Ray Anderson, Tony Llewellyn-Jones.

results.title: A Touch of sensitivity
results.creator_credit: Stephen Rose and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
A sense of touch is vital to our well-being and yet we often ignore it to our cost. This film reports on recent research in Britain and America which has led to some remarkable findings.
